DIV1.P: BARNABY BRITTLE; OR, A WIFE AT HER WIT'S END.
BARNABY BRITTLE; OR, A WIFE AT HER WIT'S END: A FARCE; IN TWO ACTS: AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
ALTERED FROM MOLIERE AND BETTERTON: WITH ADDITIONS.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR S. BLADON, No 13, PATER-NOSTER-ROW. M,DCC,LXXXVIII Entered at STATIONERS HALL.

DIV1.HEAD: BARNABY BRITTLE; OR, A WIFE AT HER WIT'S END.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE. A Street.

SP.P: TIS love, Jeffery—I have an intrigue here.
An intrigue!—with whom sir?
With pretty Mrs. Brittle, the glassman's wife, the landlord of yonder house.
Give you good fortune, sir!

Damaris, her chambermaid, I have al∣ready won, who gives me all the encouragement I can wish for: she says, the husband's jealous to distraction, and that his wife loves company and courtship most extremely.
You have ground enough to work on, I think, sir.
I have a letter ready, which I must get conveyed to Damaris; she'll give it to her mistress, and send me an answer instantly:—thou can'st con∣vey it very privately?
Do you think this life will last for ever, sir? shall no condition 'scape you?
Good wise Jeffery, spare your counsel and deliver my letter for me—Take it.
Do not trust me, sir; I say do not trust me. I have a very squeamish stomach, and I shall spoil this business; therefore do not trust me.
I have a mind to marry, myself, and have no mind to be a cuckold, sir.
Why, thou a cuckold, fool?

If I carry this letter, sir, and you dishon∣our this honest citizen, then I am partly the occa∣sion on't; and ought not I in conscience to expect the same return when I am marry'd, sir? If I, by accident, should see a brisk young gallant with my wife, I should presently conclude that he has done the same for me; therefore, I say again, do not trust me. Exit Jeffery.
What's to be done now? Which way shall I get this letter convey'd to Damaris? Eh! is not that Clodpole, my tenant?—Egad a lucky thought; he's a simple, honest fellow, and will be glad to serve me.
He shall do it.—Ha! Clodpole, how dost thou?
Pratty well and thank you worship.
Well, Clodpole, and what brings thee to town?
Why, you must know, sir, I came only to see a sweetheart of mine, one Damaris, that lives there at that house, whom I have had a kindness for some time; but she's plaguy cross and ill-natur'd to me.
And does she live there, at that house?
Yes, Sir.
Then, honest Clodpole, I must beg you to do me a small kindness.
That I will, measter—what is it?
Only to deliver this letter to Damaris your mistress—she knows what to do with it.
Troth will I, and that dirctly.
But be sure to keep this secret, and don't let any one know you have brought any letter or message from me.
O measter, never fear Clodpole. Icod I'm no fool—they must be develish cunning that gets any thing out of me—I can tell un that.
Well, go then—and if you perform this discreetly, I shall leave a couple of guineas with my servant for you.
Thank you kindly, measter: I warrant you. Icod, this is a good morning's work.
Well, sucess to you.—Egad here's old Barnaby. Exit.

These gallants flock about my house that it is grown as common as the Exchange or the Playhouses, where all sorts of company meet to laugh and talk nonsense; it makes me mad, stark mad, to think on't: I must marry a gentlewoman, with a murrain to me; and fill my house with her proud,
vain kindred. Well, Barnaby Brittle, you have nobody to thank but yourself for this: you must marry above your quality, and now you see the effect on't.
How now, wife, whither away so fast?
I am going to Ranelagh Gardens with my cousin Philadelphia.
To Ranelagh Gardens!
Yes, and thence to the play, where we shall have such sport!
How! Sport! Wife.
'Tis the pleansantest thing in the whole world, to have a flock of wild gallants fluttering about two or three ladies. 'Tis a better entertain∣ment than any part of the play can be.
Pray stay a little; why, now, is this a dress for Barnaby Brittle's wife?
No: but 'tis a dress for a gentlewoman, for Sir Peter Pride's daughhter, Sir.

O citizens! citizens! How are the times alter'd since your wives wore high crown'd hats, Farendin gowns, red cloth petticoats, good leather shoes, and troop'd the streets in pattens!—Now your feet must be furnish'd at one pound one a pair. Your silks must be bought in Pall-Mall: Ludgate Hill, and the Minories have no choice. Well may we decay when our wives, like French mistresses, send our money abroad.

If the times are alter'd with the wives, so they are with the husbands, since they wore their own thin lank hair, that look'd like the fringe of a blanket, or the strings of a bunch of leeks: you can now wear the best and richest cloaths. The times
are chang'd since I was married too; did not you promise me that I shou'd keep my coach, and live like what I was.
Yes, a beggar. (aside)
Did not I marry you when I could have had—
Nobody else. (aside)

The best of quality—but that my parents preferr'd you.—You said you were able to keep a coach, and you wou'd do it, that I might outshine the best of all the city.—Every tradesman keeps his wife a carriage even tho' he break at the year's end for't.
No coach—exercise is wholeseme—ever go on foot, wife
Why, Pestle the apothecary keeps his wife a coach, and is not worth half so much as you are; besides hav'nt you fin'd for alderman?
Ay, and if I had not fin'd for fool, in giving your relations a thousand pounds, you might have had a coach.
Well let me have it and I'll save it in other things. I'll catch cold else every winter, and it shall cost you more in slops; but I must not stay any longer, my cousin waits. (going)
Hold, wife, if you please, you shall not go
Indeed, husband, if you please, I will go.
Truly, my pretty-fac'd wife, I shall make you tarry.
Truly, my sweet-fac'd husband, you cannot nor you shall not.—I will go, and stay me if you can or dare.
Hast thou the impudence to say this to my face!—Do not provoke me, do not.
Where's the danger, pray?
Do not force me to use you worse than I in∣tended.
The worst you cou'd do you have done already; you marry'd me against my will, and do you think I will not be reveng'd for't.
Hold that damnable tongue of yours, thou island crocodile, or I shall do you a mischief; the devil tempts me to it strangely; I have a mind to claw thee much.

Do your worst, I defy you: I am a gen∣tlewoman on both sides, by my father and mother, and shall I suffer an under citizen, a pitiful glassman, to make a slave of me? I might have wedded a nobleman, and have mov'd in my proper sphere: and did I lose this and marry a sneaking glassman that will not allow me christian liberty? My comfort is I have parents who will not see me wrong'd—I'll send for them directly, and let them know how I am used by you. Exit into the house

What shall I do?—I shall be damnably tor∣mented with this father and mother of her's— Well, gentlefolks of birth and quality, may be fine people for ought I know; but I wish it had been high treason to marry any body but one another:— My own house is a hell to me; I never come home, but the Devil, in the shape of some vexation or other, is got hither before me—Why, look, there he is now.
SP.STAGE: Enter Clodpole out of Brittle's House.
SP.P: What the devil has that fellow been doing there?
How that man eyes me! Is he not a spy, set to watch me? He saw me come forth from the glassman's house, and may discover me.
I'll speak to him.—A good day to you friend!
You do not live at that house, friend, do you?
No, sir, no; I only come to prepare an entertainment for to-morrow.
For to-morrow! Tell me who makes it, will you?
Mum!
Who?
Peace.
What do'st thou mean? You came out of that house.
You must not tell it tho'.
Why?
Softly—I am afraid we shall be overhead.
No, never fear it man.
The business I came about was to deliver a letter to the mistress of that house, in the behalf of a fine young gentleman: but nobody must know of this—you understand me?
Yes, yes.
For look you, I was charg'd not to be seen when I came forth, therefore do not discover me.
I warrant you.
I can be very secret when I am commanded, sir.
Yes, yes, I find you can.

Her husband, they say, is the jealousest old coxcomb in the whole city; so ill-natur'd a fel∣low that he deserves not to have love made to his wife. If this shou'd come to his knowledge, sir, he'd play the devil—you understand me?
Yes, yes, very well.
He must know nothing of all this.
No, no.
They'll cozen him, and do it privately— you understand me?
Nobody better—but what's the gentleman's name, friend?
I can never remember these hard names— I think he is call'd Mr. Love—I, I, Mr. Love∣more.—He has a brave estate in our country, sir.
O, I know him very well; he lodges at—
The draper's over the way.
The very same.
I assure you he is the honestest gentleman I ever was acquainted with; he gave me a piece of gold only to carry the letter to this gentlewoman.
Well, have you delivered it!
Yes, yes; and there's one Damaris, a notable girl, I warrant her; she knew my business before I spake to her: she carry'd me to her mistress in∣stantly.
Ah! damn'd witch!
In troth that Damaris is a very pretty wench: the match between us is half made up, for I have got my own consent; there wants nothing but her's.
You'll soon have that, to be sure. Well and what answer made the gentlewoman to the young gallant's letter?

She bid me tell him—stay, can I remember it? That she was very much oblig'd to him for his kindness to her, and desir'd him to appoint some place where they might safely meet, and be very careful that her husband did not discover 'em
O vile woman! (aside)
Then he will be fitted for his jealousy:— will it not be very pleasant?
Yes, certainly.
Farewel—mum! not a word of this: be sure you keep this secret—you understand me?
Never doubt me.
For my part, I'll make as if I knew no∣thing of it: I can be cunning when I have a mind to it: They shall get nothing out of me, I warrant 'em:—you understand me? Farewel. Exit.

Good by.—Well, Barnaby Brittle, now you find how your wife uses you! This 'tis to marry a gentlewoman: had she been a good honest trades∣man's daughter, I might have taken the liberties of the city, and have drubb'd her from Wapping to Westminster. A wicked jade! to promise a meeting to a wild young fellow, oh!—I'll not endure it: I'll complain to her parents instantly: now they shall see I have reason for my jealousy—and here the come most opportunely for't.
You seem disorder'd, son! Pray what's the matter now?
I am mad, stark mad!
Good lord, son, where were you bred, that you use us with no more respect? Is that hat of yours nail'd on? Is it not possible, son, to teach you how to behave yourself to persons of our quality?
Pray, mother-in-law, forbear your instruc∣tions now.
Again! Will you never leave that ill-bred trick of calling me mother-in-law? Is it not as easy for you to say madam?
'Slife, if you call me son-in-law, I know no reason why I may not call you mother-in-law.

Yes, there are many reasons; if you do not know 'em, I'll instruct you, son: tho' I am your
mother-in-law, yet 'tis not sir for you to use that name to a person of my quality; there's a great dif∣ference 'tween you and me: pray know yourself, and keep your distance too.
Enough, love. Son-in-law, proceed me∣thodically, tell me the business.
Well, since I must, I'll tell you methodical∣ly—Sir Peter—
Softly, son-in law; know 'tis ill-breed∣ing to call persons of my birth and education by their names; to those above us we should say, to the ladies, madam, to the men, sir, short.
Why then, sir, short (if you'll have it so) my wife makes me—
Nay, but son, know you must not say your wife, when you speak of our daughter, son.
Lord! Will you make me still madder? —Is not my wife, my wife?
Yes, son-in-law, she is your wife; but 'tis not fit you shou'd call her so: you cou'd do no more if you were married to your equal.

Puh! what a rout and a fus is here! the devil take all ceremonies; for the love of goodness lay your gentility aside, and give me leave to speak what I have a mind to:—I tell you I am ill-satisfy'd with my marriage.
Your reason, son-in-law!—Do you think it no advantage then to be ally'd to the honourable family of the Prides?
A noble family that will make all your children gentlemen?
Yes, yes, I believe my children may be gentlemen, for they're like to be of a gentleman's getting: but I shall be a cuckold, madam, unless I take great care.
Pray, son, explain yourself: we will not maintain her in ill actions: we'll be the first shall do you justice on her.

There's a young gentleman makes love to her, and she receives his courtship—this gallant, under pretence of visiting your kinswoman, who lodges in my house, watches for all occasions to cor∣rupt her, madam.
By this good day, I had rather strangle her with my own hands then she shou'd stain the honor of her family.
And I'll run my sword thro' her and her gallant too, if she forfeits her reputation.—But are you sure all this is true?
Ay, ay, too sure on't.
Have a care, son, for these are ticklish points, and ought not to be dally'd with.
All I have told you is a certain truth.
Go you, love, and talk with your daughter, while my son-in-law and I seek out this amorous gallant. (Exit Lady.) Follow me, son, and you shall see how vigorously I'll mange this affair.
Here he comes, sir, to save you the trouble of seeking him.
Do you know me, sir?
No, sir, not that I well remember.
I am call'd Sir Peter Pride, sir.
I am glad to hear it, sir.
I am known at court; I had the honor in my youth to behave myself gallantly in the late civil wars; I was in every battle that was fought in the kingdom, from Edgehill to Naseby.
Very good, sir.
My grandfather, Sir Alexander Pride, was so considerable in his time, that he had permission granted him by the parliament to sell his land and follow Captain Drake to the West Indies.
Sir, I believe all this.

Now, know, sir, I am inform'd that you make love to a young gentlewoman for whom I am concern'd, because she is my daughter, sir; and this man you see here has the honor to be marry'd to her: I am glad I have found you, to know of you the bottom of this business.
Pray, sir who told you this?
One that knows it to be true, sir.
Whoe'er reported this of me is a rascal: tell me his name—I'll cut the villain's tongue out.
O lud! what will become of me now?
This, sir, you say, is the gentlewoman's husband?
Yes, sir, 'twas he made this complaint to me.
You! Sir; did you?—'Tis well you have the honor to be related to Sir Peter Pride, else I shou'd teach you what it were to raise such reports of me.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Pride, Wife, and Damaris.

SP.P: Well jealousy's a very troublesome thing: I bring my daughter to clear herself in the face of the whole world.
Was it you, madam, that told your hus∣band I made love to you?
I! sir—pray how shou'd I tell him so! you never spoke to me before, that I remembered.
Look you there, I knew she was abused.
Madam I have more respect, and more reverence for your brave father and your honour∣able mother, to have the least thought of affront∣ing you.
Now, son, do you here this?
Are you yet satisfied? What say you now?
I say it is all damn'd cunning: and since I must speak, 'tis not half an hour since she receiv'd a letter from him.
Did I receive a letter from him?—Dama∣ris, on your oath now?
O! sir, I never heard a falser thing in my life.
Hold your peace, carrion; I know your tricks too well: you were to have introduc'd this gallant.
Who, I?
Yes, hussy, you.
How full of malice is this wicked world! —To suspect me who am innocence itself!
Hold your tongue, baggage, or I shall cudgel your hide for you—You are not a gentle∣man's daughter—I may do what I will with you.
This is such an abuse I have not power to answer him: Alas! If I am to be blam'd for any thing, 'tis for loving him to well.
So it is, Madam.
Ay, Damaris, that's my greatest misfor∣tune. And to be thus wrongfully accus'd, Oh! oh! Who can endure it? I will not stay to be thus abus'd.
Go, jealous coxcomb, go: thou do'st not deserve to have such an honest woman to thy wife.

No, madam, he deserves to be made what
he fears to be: truly, sir, I think you ought to make love to my mistress, if 'twere for nothing but to punish him: do it, Sir, I promise you, you shall have my assistance.
There's the flower of brimstone, and cream of tartar!
Truly, son, you deserve all this they threaten you with: your ridiculous behaviour sets all the world against you.
Go, clown, and learn to use a gentle∣woman better. I'll follow her, my dear, and com∣fort her.
Do my lady.
Why this is the devil, to be in the wrong when a man's in the right; but can I get nobody to believe me!
You see how unjustly I have been accus'd sir: you are a man of honour: I demand satis∣faction for this affront I have receiv'd.
'Tis but just, and you shall have it, Sir. Come, son, give the gentleman satisfaction.
Satisfaction, sir, for what?
For accusing him thus falsely.
I don't believe I have accus'd him falsely
That's all one; he denies it; and 'tis enough if a gentleman unsays what he has said.
Very pretty truly!
No more delays, but do as I command you.
Um! What will you have me do?
Trust me, you shall not do too much? first take off your hat, for he's a gentleman and you are none—do it I say—that's well—say after me, sir—
Sir.
I ask your pardon.
I ask your pardon.
For the ill thoughts I had of you.
For the ill thoughts I had of you.
But now, sir, I beseech you to believe—
But now sir, I beseech you to believe—
That I am for ever, sir, your humble ser∣vant.
How! Your humble servant to him who wou'd make me a cuckold, sir?
How's this!
'Tis enough, sir—I am satisfy'd.
No, sir, he shall say it in form—that I am for ever your humble servant—
Then the devil take me if I will say it—
Sir I have troubled you too much.—Your servant, sir.
Sir, your humble servant — Now I hope you see my son is match'd in a family that will not see him wrong'd. Come a long Barnaby.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE. A Chamber in Brittle's House

SP.P: I guest at first this business came from you.

In good faith, Damaris, I only spoke two or three words to a man that saw me come out of our house, to desire him not to speak of it, and he betray'd me.—Your neighbours are horribly given to prating.
Mr. Lovemore made an excellent choice when he pick'd you out for an ambassador; he's like to make a successful treaty on't.
Hereafter I'll be more cunninger, and take more care. Hear me a little.
What shou'd I hear?
Turn thy face towards me.
Well, Sir, what now?
Damaris, mistress Damaris.
What ail'st thou?
Can'st thou not guess what I wou'd say to thee?
No, by my troth, not I.
Why then I love thee, Damaris.
Indeed!
Yes, indeed, do I or the devil take me—I hope you'll believe me when I swear?— I never look upon thee but my heart jolts in my stomach, like a cart in an uneven way.—You under∣stand me.
An excellent simile!
What do'st thou do to make thyself look so prettily?
What should I do?
We won't make much ado about this busi∣ness; but if thou wilt marry me— (Goes to kiss her)
Stand off, or I shall box you, depend on't
Cruel, savage, barbarous, inhuman creature!
Be gone, and tell your master, the old man at home.
Farewell fiint, pebble, rock, marble, or any thing that's harder. Exit.
Here comes my Mistress.
Lud! I look like a fright to day, Da∣maris—I am dress'd intolerably—this gown is wretchedly made, and does not become me: when was Thieveskirt the mantua maker here?
Yesterday, ma'am with her bill.
Her bill?

She says, ma'am, you bid her bring it, and
left word with Jeremy it was the seventh bill for the same work, and that she is in great distress for her money.
No doubt she is—every body is in dis∣tress now, and a mantua-maker shou'd not be out of the fashion.
What shall I do when she comes again?
You must—you must send her away again, I think: plague a gentlewoman indeed with her bill! I wonder in a civiliz'd nation there are no laws against duns.
Well, have you delivered my messages?
Why I think so—how many did you give me forsooth?
Madam—always say.
Mrs. Thingumbob, at the Hog's-head, was gone out chud seem.
Madam—
Madam.
Well, and how is Mrs. Squabble—Mrs. Lockup—Mrs. Loveit—Mrs. Setup—Mrs. Costly and sister—Mrs.—
Wauns! Mistress's tongue goes like the mill at my father's orchard end, that scares crows from the cherry-tree.
Hold your audacious tongue.
Well, Mrs. Setup at the Boar's-head, which you call the Hog's-head, was gone out you say, Clumsey?

So she was—yeas they are well, madam, and hope you are well; and they'll all, or some of them, come to see you—so they gives their loves— no sar∣vices—an—madam, that's all, madam—there's ma∣dam enough for you I think, if you know when you have enough.

This body must be sent about his busi∣ness—he will disgrace me before company—I have been teaching him the distinguishing rap these three days, and yet he'll knock with the sneaking tap of a tradesman—Damaris, bring tea: dy'e hear, when you wait, sarrah, don't bring the bread and butter dangling in your hand as you did yesterday, you filthy brute, you—remember to bring nothing without a plate.
Yes, madam. Exit Jer.

I declare I am perfectly fatigued for want of something to do, I wish Lovemore was here to squire me to the Park—O dear me, where's Misha? Pretty thing, I ha'nt seen her these two hours.—Call Misha. Calling out without.
Jeremy.
Well now, what's wanted?
Bring Misha up to mistress.
I hope the sweet creature will have pretty pups. I am determined to keep them all.
Well, where's Misha?
By the mess I can't bring her, not I.
Why not pray, is she so heavy?
No madam, 'tis not for that, but I can't make her lie upon a plate for the blood o'me, though I cuff'd and thump'd her never so much.
A plate! Did you ever see a dog brought on a plate; did you monster?
Why no. But how do I know your London fashion. You tould me just now to bring naught with∣out a pleat—so you did.
What living things? Did I say living things? Pursuing Jeremy.
Living things! 'Sblood the devil wou'd not live with you Exit.
My patience is quite exhausted with such dolts of servants.—Damaris I'll take a walk in the garden; fetch my clogs hither.
Yes ma'am—Jeremy!
Well now what want ye?
Bring mistress's clogs directly.
I'll take a turn or two, and then go with my cousin for the evening.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Jeremy with the Clogs on a Plate.

SP.P: Here they be madam.
Mercy be good unto me—I am quite in an agony—why thou senseless ideot, was ever a pair of dirty clogs brought on a plate? (Strikes him.)
Why the clogs ben't living things, be they?
Out of my sight thou stupid log.

STAGE.HI: Throwing the Clogs and Plate at him.

SP.P: What the murrain is the matter now—are you not asham'd, wife, to destroy things wilfully thus —when thou knowest how chargeable necessaries are?—be gone Jeremy and mind the shop. Exit Jer.

DIV3.STAGE: Mrs. Brittle beats off the boy

SP.P: I see I might as well hold my tongue—I had as good sit down and comfort myself;—when 'tis at the worst it may mend—come who knows—I may have the luck to show the queen in her true colours; then I think she'll be out of countenance—ah dear madam fortune! let me but live to prove myself a cuckold—then I shall die contented. Exit.
WELL, Damaris, have you given the sig∣nal?
There was no need of a signal; I found Mr. Lovemore in you closet, madam.
My dear Mrs. Brittle, I have taken the opportunity of old Argus' going out, and the mo∣ment I saw him hobble over the kennel, came upon the wings of—I was going to say Love— to meet thee.

I hope you don't flatter yourself with sup∣posing I entertain any unlawful inclinations—I endure your company, indeed, only to lighten the hours which my old tyrant makes otherwise insup∣portable. He's gone for the whole evening to his club of cits like himself.—Get the cards Dama∣ris. [Exit Damaris.] —I'll have my revenge.
That you shall with all my heart. We will employ the time much better than at cards— my life—my soul. Catching hold of her.
Bless me, what do you mean?
O ma'am, my master's come in.
The devil! which way shall I go out then?
What shall we do?—here, here, quick, get behind the closet door, and don't even breathe for your life. (Retires.) I hear him coming— (Falls down.) Oh! Oh!
What's the matter?
Oh, my poor mistess—help, sir,—where have you put him ma'am? (aside)
Oh my leg!—My leg!—into the closet.
What is the matter, dearee?
I fear I have broke my leg.
Heaven forbid (tho' I wish it may be so, then she can't stir abroad these two months.) Where∣abouts have you hurt it love?
Just in my instep—Oh! Oh!
Help, Damaris, and set your mistress in a chair. How camest thou to fall, Pudsey?

Why, hearing you were come in unex∣pectedly—I ran to meet my own dear, and my heel caught hold of my cloaths, and down I fell— I shall be better if you will lead me to the sopha, that I may lay down a little.
No, no, let me rub it a little—I don't find any thing broke.
I wish your neck was broke. (aside.)
It's only a sprain—I have some camphorat∣ed spirits of wine in the closet—I'll fetch it, and bathe it with that; its very good for you; what's in the closet?
O dear numps, don't leave me—let Dama∣ris get the spirit out of the closet.
Ay, I'll fetch it directly.
No, no, she'll do some mischief—I'll go myself.
Oh!—I shall swoon—hold me numps—I shall, I shall—have you any hartshorn, dearee?
Yes, my dear, plenty—how is your leg now?
Oh! rub it gently. (He rubs, she beckons Lovemore to go.)
Here, sir, here's the bottle. (Squats down to hide Lovemore.)
What is the devil in you, hussey; have you a mind to lame me too?—Why don't you pull out the cork?
Hang the cork—do rub on, dear numps.
Now! now! (aside to Lovemore.)
What's now, now?
Why now the cork's out.—Lord, you don't mind my mistress's foot.
Where lies the pain now?
Just where you are.
Come, try to stand up.
(Rising) Gently!—Ah! my dear life—I cannot bear it. (Catches Brittle round the neck to prevent his seeing Lovemore.)
Why you will smother me—Damaris, call for more help— (Turns, and sees Lovemore.) Hey! who the devil are you, pray?
What will become of us? (aside)
I am amaz'd, sir, you shou'd leave your doors open; no servant in the way to take a mes∣sage?
Had you any to send up, sir?—Pray; sir, who are you, and what do you want here?
My business is with you, sir.
Impudence assist him! (aside)
The affair I came upon requires privacy.

(Very likely) Sir, I keep my private ears
for my public friends—therefore your business I insist upon knowing.
Sir your reputation is concern'd in what I have to say.
My reputation does not depend upon your tongue, I'm sure, and I'll not stir a foot.
But, sir, my regard for the lady prevents —pray is not she your wife?
Yes sir, and what then?—What have you to say against my wife?
Sir I have nothing to say against your wife—'tis only against you.
Speak out, sir.
Nay, then now, sir, I am employ'd by Sir Andrew Gudgeon.
Gudgeon! I believe you have mistaken your fish.—I know no man of that name
Harkee, sir, a word—you know his wife I suppose?—Sir Andrew will have satisfaction before he and you have done.
Satisfaction! for what pray?
(loud) for dishonouring him with his wife, since you must know.
How! Oh mercy!
What the devil do you mean? You must not think to make a gudgeon of me, sir.

Nor you must not think to make a cuck∣old of Sir Andrew, sir; I don't value your high words, nor your big looks—I am a Proctor in the Bishop's Court, and employed by Sir Andrew to ex∣hibit a libel against you for crim. con.
Oh! Barnaby! I wonder you have the assurance to look your honest wife in the face— ungrateful man—have I hugg'd and kiss'd you for this? (crying)
Oh! what a rogue you must be—you who have so tender and loving a wife of your own!—Oh! I shall break my heart.
To say nothing of the sin, the shame of it, at your advanced time of life—
Was ever poor man thus baited?
Ah, numps, I never thought you wou'd have used me thus.
This is a trick—zounds, you dog, get out of my house.
Get you out with your bail. He must undergo the sentence usual in these cases, to stand in a white sheet.
I'll white sheet you, you dog—Go, Dama∣ris fetch my barber, he's a constable—why don't you go hussey?
I'll not stir a step, you wicked old wretch
Sir, I am not afraid of a constable, but the less noise you make in this affair the better, Sir Nicholas.
Sir Nicholas! Here must be some mis∣take; sir, my husband is no Sir Nicholas.
What say you madam, is not this Sir Ni∣cholas Widgeon?
No, nor Woodcock neither—you assassinat∣ing dog, as you shall find.
Bless me, what a mistake? I ask pardon, sir, but I was directed next door to the sun.
Sir Nicholas lives the next house but one, and I am happy at the mistake.
A very pretty mistake truly, to come into a man's house, and abuse him, and threaten him with a white sheet, and then think it recompence to ask pardon, and say 'tis a mistake
I assure you I am griev'd at the accident, I wish I knew how to make you satisfaction.
You may know directly, by walking out at that door.
Madam, can you forgive the error I have committed?
Freely sir; the pleasure of finding my hus∣band innocent, inclines me to pardon the mistake.
You are too good, madam. Your ser∣vant, madam; I assure you I am quite out of countenance.
Thank ye, sir, thank ye, enough said—your servant.
If you should ever have any business in Doctor's Commons, I am yours entirely.
I'll see the gentleman out love—your ser∣vant Exeunt and returns.
Egad, Damaris this was well manag'd— a troublesome old—well, is the proctor gone, dearee?
Yes, truly, the rogue is on the right side of the door at last, which is well barr'd and bolted for the night—go, wife, go to your chamber.
Yes, dearest. You won't stay long, I hope.

No, sweet one. I don't know how it is— I firmly believe my wife plays me a trick—but I can't prove it. What to do I know not—beat her, I can't, I believe; turn her away, I dare not— adod it is a very hard circumstance, that a man shall be sure he is a cuckold, and can make no∣body believe it but himself — 'tis not so with my neighbours; if you step into 'Change Alley, you'll see a thousand honest fellows that every one be∣lieves to be cuckolds but themselves.—Well, I'll say no more but eat my mess of sugar-sops, and to bed; let all take warning by me, and never
marry a poor gentlewoman, for you wed thei whole family, and entail a plague upon your pos∣terity.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE. Outside of Brittle's House

SP.P: Sir, Mrs. Damaris bid me tell you her mis∣tress will come hither to you instantly. Is not the night very unkind, sir, to be so dark?
Quite contrary; it hinders me, Clodpole, from being seen. Hush! I hear 'em coming, Clodpole.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Wife and Damaris from the House

SP.P: Damaris.
Madam.
Leave the door half open.
I have so, madam.
Where are you, my fair mistress?
Here, Mr. Lovemore.
Let me kiss this pretty hand of yours.
Now we are safe, my husband is a asleep, sir.
Let us retire and walk; the night is plea∣sant.
Lead me, sir—Come, Damaris.
Damaris! Where art thou, Damaris?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Brittle out of the House.

SP.P: I heard my wife steal softly down stairs, and got my cloaths on as fast as I could, and fol∣low'd her. Where can the baggage be?

Why, Damaris, I say—O! art thou there? Thy mistress says her husband is very safe; he snores like any devil: he little thinks his wife and Mr. Lovemore are together now: I'd give a crown to hear what the cuckold dreams of; certainly, 'twou'd be worth laughing at. Why do'st thou not speak to me, Damaris? Let's follow 'em; and give me thy pretty little fist, that I may kiss it: ah how sweet it is! Methinks I am eating sugar-plumbs.— (Brittle gives him a slap on the Face.)— O fye! what do'st thou mean by that? I do not take this for a favour
Who's there?
Nobody, sir, nobody. Exit.
He's gone, but has informed me who my treacherous wife is with: once more I'll send for her parents; I hope I shall convince 'em now.— Ho, Jeremy—Jeremy—
Did you call, sir? (within)
Yes; come down quickly, sirrah.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Jeremy with a high Night-cap, Yawning.

SP.P: Here I am, sir.

Sirrah, look you, go to my father and mother-in-law, and tell 'em I desire they'd come hi∣ther instantly—d'ye hear, Jeremy?—Jeremy! Je∣remy! (while Brittle speaks, Jeremy stands half a∣sleep and nodding.)
Sir. (Snoring.)
Why, where are you, sirrah?
Here, sir.— (Groping)

O, that's well; I say go immediately to my father and mother-in-law, and give 'em my humble service, and tell 'em that something has happen'd—d'ye hear? and desire 'em to come hi∣ther instantly. (As Brittle is speaking; he takes hold
of Jeremy's cap, who falls down, and leaves his cap in Brittle's hand.) Ha! Why don't you answer, sirrah? (Strikes under the cap at his ear.) Jeremy? Why, what, is the devil run away with him! Je∣remy?
Here, sir. (On the ground.)
Here, you rascal! If I come to you, I'll— sirrah, come hither, or I'll beat you to death.
Ay, but won't you beat me, if I do?

SP.L: Come hither; I tell you, I won't beat you

SP.P: Ah! but won't you indeed?

I won't, indeed—come nearer booby—go to my father and mother-in-law, and pray 'em to come hither instantly; tell 'em it is a business of the greatest importance to me in the world: if you find them unwilling, desire 'em to come this once, and I'll ne'er trouble 'em more—d'ye hear?
Yes, sir, I am gone. Exit.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lovemore, Wife, Clodpole and Damaris.

SP.P: Who comes here? O! 'tis my hopeful wife! I hear her voice, and her gallant. I'll make use of the darkness of the night, and hear what 'tis they say.
I must be gone; my husband may miss me.
Will you leave me so soon?
We had discourse enough for the first time.
I have not told you half I had to say.
Farewell; another time you shall tell me; my husband will—
He is not worthy to be your husband, madam!—'Twas cruelty to marry you to so mean a fellow; Heaven never meant you for a citizen's wife.
I have heard enough— I'll in. (Exit and shuts the door)
If you have any more to say of your hus∣band, madam, dispatch, for 'tis late.
I must begone: farewell, sir.
Since you will have it so, I must obey; but I beseech you, madam, consider what torments I endure, that I must leave you; farewell. Exeunt.
Is he gone, Damaris?
Yes, madam.
Let us go in again, and make no noise.
O heavens! What shall we do? The door's lock'd. madam.
Lock'd! Call Jeremy to open it—call softly.
Jeremy—Jeremy.
(above) Jeremy—Jeremy ah ah! Have I caught you, my fine lady wife? I am glad to see you abroad at this time of the night, sweet madam.
What shall we do?—I am now at my wit's end.—What hurt is it to take the fresh air of the evening?

Alas! none in the world; 'tis the proper∣est time you could have chosen for't—you witch you: I know your whole plot, gentlewoman: I heard how sweetly you and your impudent gallant sung out my praise; I shall convince your father and mother that my complaints were just: now they shall see what a disorderly life you lead; they'll be here presently.
What shall we do now, Damaris?
A ha! What, is your prompter to wicked∣ness struck dumb? This was an accident you did not look for: now (thanks to my stars) all your plots will be laid open, to your lasting shame.
Pray, husband, let the door be open'd for me.
No, no; you shall e'en stay there 'till your parents come; they shall see what hours you keep; in the mean time—can't you think of some trick now to deliver you from this damnable adven∣ture?
No, indeed, husband; I'll disguise no∣thing from you; I'll not defend myself, or deny any thing.
Ah! 'tis because you have no hope to in∣vent any thing that will be now believ'd.
I confess I'm to blame; you have cause to be angry with me; but I beseech you do not expose me to my parent's fury. Dear Husband, I beseech you.
Ah! Now you are caught, I am your dear husband, am I? You never us'd such kind words to me before.
Trust, me I'll never give you cause to com∣plain of me again.
You'd as good say nothing—farewell.
Pray stay, hear me but one word before you go.
Well—and pray what have you to say now?
I confess I have been to blame; I only pray you to forget a fault I heartily repent of, and ask your pardon for.—I protest, dear, 'tis you, and only you, I love.
Ah! wheedling crocodile.
Will you not believe me, then?
No.
Let me intreat you.
No! I'll have the world see what you are
If you make me desperate, know a woman in that condition is capable of doing any thing.
Ha, ha, ha! What will your sweet lady∣ship do?
That which you may repent of; I'll kill myself with this knife, if you deny me. (holding her fan like a dagger)
Very good—

'Twill not be so good as you imagine nei∣ther: when I am dead, no one will doubt but that you were my murderer; I am not the first wife that has kill'd herself to be reveng'd of a cruel, hard hearted husband.
O! your servant; killing one's self has been long out of fashion, madam.
If you 'scape the law, my ghost shall haunt you for it.
Ah! If I were but rid of your person now, I shou'd not much fear your ghost hereafter.
I am just doing it.
Hold, madam—you cannot be in earnest.
Stand off, I'll kill thee else—there—
Oh, she has don't—she has don't—Oh!

So—now you find too late, I did not jest; you can witness, Damaris, who was my murderer; commend me to my parents; tell 'em my last re∣quest is, that they will see my death reveng'd upon my cruel husband.

She's gone! she's gone! O jealous mon∣ster! To murder so sweet a creature! I'll to her father and mother instantly; my witness will be enough to hang you; you were the cause of her death; and I may with a safe conscience swear 'twas you that did it. (they retire.)
All's very still. Is it possible she can be so malicious to kill herself only to have me hang'd? —I'll light a candle and come down immediately.
Damaris?
Madam.
Come hither, and stand up close by me.

STAGE.HI: (As he enters, they slip in and shut the door).

SP.P: Can a woman's wickedness extend so fa to murder herself, only to be reveng'd on me? Ah! here's nobody: wife! wife! I might have believed this at first; when the cunning quean found neither prayers nor threats wou'd work upon me, she ran away: better and better still; this will convince her parents with a vengeance, and render her odious to the whole world—Ha! how the deuce came this door lock'd? Open the door there quickly.
Away, you drunken sot; get you to the tavern from whence you came. Is this an hour to come home in? Is this a life for an honest man to lead?
Shame on you, master! to stay abroad with your harlots and jades so late, and use your good wife in this scandalous manner.
Go, go, base man; I'll endure it no lon∣ger; I'll complain to my father and mother on't.
Have you the impudence to say all this to my very face?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Jeremy with a lanthorn; Sir Peter and Lady under an umbrella.

SP.P: I beseech you, sir, and you, dear madam, to come hither, and do me justice on a husband whom jealousy and wine have quite distracted; he has sent for you himself, to witness the greatest piece of extravagance that ever yet was heard of. There he stands, just now come from the tavern, madam:—how may nights do I sit up for him!
Was there ever such a devil!
If you hearken to him, he'll tell you, that whilst he slept, I stole away from him, and a thousand idle stories of the same nature, sir.
'Tis the strangest impudence in the whole world, to call us out of our beds at this time of the night.
I must confess I never saw so much im∣pudence before.—What is your meaning, son, to use us thus?
O! my dear father, I'm weary of my life, and can no longer endure such a wicked hus∣band; my patience is tir'd; he has said a thousand injurious things to me beside.
Troth, son, you're a very unworthy fel∣low. Do not anger me any more—do not, I say, 'tis not safe.
Can I endure all this! Pray, sir, hear me but speak two words.
Stand farther off—you smell of wine most intolerably.
Out upon him; 'tis enough to make one sick.

Well then, if you'll hear me, I'll stand farther off—I swear to you I have not been out of
my house to night, nor three minutes out of my bed: 'twas she that was abroad.
Now, madam, did not I tell you he'd say this before?
I call all the stars to witness.
Come, trouble us no more, but ask her pardon.
I ask her pardon!—What, she offends, and I must ask—
Do not expostulate with me lest you re∣pent it.
Ah! Barnaby Brittle, what hast thou brought thyself to!
Daughter, come down.
Make haste, that your hushand may ask your pardon before we go.
I'll pull down your stubborn heart—I'll teach you what it is to abuse a gentlewoman so.
Come, clown, and ask your wife forgiveness, quickly.
Shall I forgive him, madam? No; 'tis impossible! I desire to be divorc'd from him.
Daughter, such separations are scanda∣lous: tho' he's so foolish to desire it, yet you ought to be wise, child: have patience, and try him once again.
After so many affronts, I can't endure him longer.
You must: I command you to do it.
That stops my mouth: your power is ab∣solute—Come, dear, give me your hand; we will be friends. I ask your pardon.

Q.L: Sure I was mad with a kind spouse like this,
To think of wronging such a lovely piece;
Behold his eyes so bright, his skin so sleek,
His winning love, and dimple in his cheek.
Well 'tis resolved: I'll strive with Hymen's grace
To doat upon this venerable face.

SP.L: Patience long time has been the husband's cure,
For what we cannot mend, we must endure;
Wives at the best, they say, are but an evil,
But an unequal match is sure the devil.

DIV1.HEAD: TRAGEDIES, COMEDIES, and OPERAS, in 8vo. 1s. 6d. each, printed for S. BLADON, No. 13, Pater-noster-Row.

LIST.ITEM: Follies of a Day, by Holcroft
Maid of Bath, by Mr. Foote
Word to the Wise, by Kelly
